raw_comment: The first thing to note is that for every row the young women's percentage was greater than the young men's. This is likely due to a variety of factors one of which I believe is that parents are more protective over their daughters compared to their sons. I would assume a good amount of these responses are from young adults whose parents require them to call or text at least once a week. There are a lot of things I wonder about the graph, one of them being if there is a difference between the teens and the people in their thirties. The survey targeted people from the ages 18-34, which in my opinion is a pretty large gap. I would be interested in learning how getting older affects how often you reach out to your parents.  There are many ways to categorize this data, in college or not in college, taken or single, and living in a different time zone or the same time zore are just some of the many ways that this data could be explored. I would also wonder if the survey counted reaching out if the young adult was just responding to a previous text from a parent. Reaching out, especially for texting, is a little ambiguous. Personally, I call parents at least once a week and text them very often throughout the week. I don't visit them due to the distance thought. This all lines up very well with the data. A title could be "C'mon, they deserve a call"
ace_sentences: For every row, the percentage of young women was greater than the percentage of young men.
This difference is likely due to several factors.
One factor is that some parents are more protective of their daughters than of their sons.
Many responses may be from young adults.
Some parents require these young adults to call or text at least once a week.
I wonder if there is a difference between teenagers and people in their thirties.
The survey targeted people who are at least 18 years old and at most 34 years old.
This age range is a large gap.
I am interested in how getting older affects how often a person reaches out to his or her parents.
There are many ways to categorize this data.
One way is whether a person is in college or not in college.
One way is whether a person is taken or single.
One way is whether a person lives in a different time zone or in the same time zone as the parents.
I wonder if the survey counted reaching out when a young adult only responded to a previous text from a parent.
The term reaching out is ambiguous.
The term reaching out is especially ambiguous for texting.
I call my parents at least once a week.
I text my parents very often throughout the week.
I do not visit my parents because of the distance.
My behavior aligns with the data.
A possible title is: C'mon, they deserve a call.
